content.div:
Without their irate neighbour, who knows whether the new Plants and Animals album, The End of That, would have turned out as it did?

During a recent interview at the Montreal home of multi-instrumentalist and singer Warren Spicer, the three group members -- Spicer, drummer Matthew Woodley and lead guitarist Nicolas Basque -- settled in to connect the dots on how a complaint from the man next door unlocked a way to complete the album.

They were recording at La Frette, a homey recording facility near Paris that Basque likened in appearance to a Westmount house. They had returned to the studio, where they had done part of their previous album, La La Land. The amps were turned up in the living room, as the band willed itself to improve on sessions that were, Spicer recalled, getting sluggish.

"I was really stressed," Spicer said. "We were, like, 'Today, we're going to have a great day. We're really going to get a lot of work done.'"

But it was not to be.

It was a long weekend -- France's Labour Day -- and the long-suffering gentleman living next to La Frette was planning on a family barbecue unhindered by rock 'n' roll. The studio owner, Olivier Bloch-Laine, heard from him, in no uncertain terms. The outburst was, Spicer said, an emotional explosion.

The result: a forced day off for the group, only an hour into the session. An impromptu run or an unplanned reading session were among the only options.

"I thought 'Oh, we're so screwed. This is a disaster,'" Spicer said. "And little did we know â€¦"

"It was the old blessing in disguise," Woodley chimed in.

Flights home were postponed, easing the looming deadline pressure.

After dinner that day, the group retreated to the downstairs wine-cellar area, with a carpeted studio room, and worked on the album's title song. A different sound -- more like the 1970s, Woodley said -- changed the whole feel of the playing and the recording was finished in the newly discovered room, at a more leisurely pace.

"It saved us," Spicer said.

The result of the extension was a disciplined album that keeps most songs in the three or four-minute range and eschews the dense, exploratory sound of La La Land in favour of crisp hooks and prominent acoustic strumming.

If a recurring theme in previous interviews with the group members is their ongoing attempt to learn how to craft a song with a beginning, middle and end. With The End of That, they seem to have achieved that goal.

"I'm not sure the new album is a reaction, necessarily, to La La Land," Spicer said. "It doesn't feel like it. It feels like we did that album, toured like crazy and then just started writing again. I guess, from a personal point of view, in terms of songwriting, La La Land was veiled in lots of misdirection or smoke and mirrors. I was kind of hiding, and the music was a lot denser, a lot more textured -- a completely different beast from this record."

Demos of some 20 songs were made, with final recordings of 17 completed -- with even a Broadway-styled composition attempted (although perhaps it might have been more like Broadway meets Portishead). In the end, 11 tracks made it onto the album.

"In the past, we probably never really had enough material," Spicer said. "We were working to fill up the record, as opposed to working to cut it down."

Spicer, who wrote the lyrics, said an attempt to write songs from a character's point of view on the last album didn't work for him. "The struggle this time was to try to address things honestly and sing songs from the real part of me," he said.

Some of the songs involve the thorny subject of commitment, a topic that came naturally, given that Spicer had left a long-standing relationship before the new disc was recorded. Increasing domesticity in his environment, he said, provided a crossroad experience for him.

"When you're a musician in your late 20s, there are not many people who are married and have kids," he said. "And then something happens and all of a sudden, everybody starts getting married and having kids. I had just done the opposite and left a long and wonderful relationship."

The title track, however, is a hopeful one. Spicer said the song is about "trying to learn from your mistakes and doing what you say you'll do. It's about the end of redundant behaviour."

Over 10 years together, the group has found it increasingly easier to communicate, Basque said, as the number and frequency of preliminary discussions for the album demonstrate.

"If recording was the second chapter and demos were the first, there was also a prologue," Woodley said. "We talked about things a lot and all the discussions made us realize that we were on the same page. We knew what we wanted. I think we had a more shared vision, even going into the demo stage."

"The decision to be doing this becomes a lot heavier," Spicer said. "When we started, you're just so excited to be doing it. It seems you worked so long just to get in the game. And then once you're in the game, it keeps changing. Life around you keeps changing and your friends are doing other things. Playing in a band is not, by any means, a stable way to make a living, or a career, for that matter. It continues to be challenging in lots of different ways. A lot of things are out of your control. As time goes on, it becomes more and more apparent that you're really making a choice to do this. But we're also happy doing it, for sure."

Plants and Animals' Canadian Tour Dates Include:

March 8, Ottawa

March 9, Quebec

March 10, Montreal

March 20, Victoria

March 21, Vancouver

March 27, Edmonton

March 28, Calgary

March 29, Saskatoon

March 30, Winnipeg

April 20, London

April 21, Toronto

link.Abstract: Nicki Minaj released new song "Stupid Hoe" today. The lyrics would seem to confirm that she'll appear at the Super Bowl with Madonna (and also that she thinks someone is a "stupid hoe").
